content:
That's correct! Since x ∈ (A∪B)^e, it means x ∈ (A∪B)^c, which implies x is in the complement of the interior of A∪B. Now, let's use this information to show that x ∈ A^e ∩ B^e.

Recall that A^e = (A^c)^i and B^e = (B^c)^i, where A^c and B^c are the complements of A and B, respectively. We want to show that x ∈ A^e and x ∈ B^e.

Since x is in the complement of the interior of A∪B, it is also in the complement of the interiors of A and B. Can you explain why this is the case and how this information can be used to show that x ∈ A^e and x ∈ B^e?
